The health care discussion and its societal issues will never be resolved. I worked in both the health care and insurance industries for many years as an Analyst for Fortune 100 Corps. I am intimately familiar with the subject.

I have been on the planet for over 50 years and have never submitted a health insurance claim of any kind. I have no children and my Father's military service covered most all of my parents medical bills.

I benefited greatly from a college minor in Human Performance and Physiology. I have never broken a bone, I watch my diet, exercise properly and regularly, no smoking, no drugs (I took 2 aspirin in 1978), no extreme sports, .... Then again, I was blessed with great genes - I have run many marathons, ultra-marathons, 10K's, Tri's, 200 mile bike races, 50 mile backpacking adventures, etc.

What amazes me is the doctors I know - and there are hundreds - are constantly blaming patients for poor diet and dangerous behavior. I have heard emergency care docs suggest 80-85% of all visits to their facilities are the result of "stupidity and insurance structure". I have heard GP's point their finger toward stupidity and ignorance at near the 90% range of their patients. When I remind these docs that smarter patients would mean far less patients, most are OK with the concept.

Nationalized health care will result in radically better health, diet and physiology education for the masses. This needs to be the primary target for discussion moving forward.

I think the chain of causation is simpler and more intuitively obvious than Nate's idea that voters engage in explicit balancing when choosing at the state and national level.

Voters get tired of whoever is power. The longer a party is perceived to be in power (perception in this case is largely the same as actually being in power) the greater the disenchantment among that party's supporters, and also the more the opposite party's adherents become angry and mobilized.

If nothing else, it's hard to have a very visible statehouse scandal if you don't control anything, while it's easy to tarnish your brand if the only thing standing between a politician and and temptation is their conscience.

Note that the effect seems greatest in the years when an incumbent president is running for re-election. In those years, a voter who has endured one party's president for four years and governor for two, is most likely to show signs of hostility toward that party.
